docs.lead_paragraph: The global drug market will grow  5 to 7 percent in 2011, to $880 billion, as higher spending in nations like China, Brazil and India makes up for slow growth and patent losses in the United States, according to a forecast released Wednesday by IMS Health, an industry data company.
docs.abstract: Drug sales in China, Brazil and India will help spur industry growth and temper lower growth in the United States.
docs.snippet: Drug sales in China, Brazil and India will help spur industry growth and temper lower growth in the United States.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria failed to reach its minimum fund-raising target needed to keep existing programs running.

headline.seo: Global Fight Against AIDS Reports Failure at Fund-Raising
headline.main: Global Fight Against AIDS Falters as Pledges Fail to Reach Goal of $13 Billion
headline.print_headline: Global Fight Against AIDS Falters as Pledges Fail to Reach Goal of $13 Billion

docs.snippet: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria failed to reach its minimum fund-raising target needed to keep existing programs running.

keywords.value: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
keywords.name: organizations

byline.contributor: Neil MacFarquhar contributed reporting from the United Nations.

docs.lead_paragraph: This will be a big month for drug approval decisions by the Food and Drug Administration. The agency faces deadlines for decisions on several drugs.
docs.abstract: Decisions on several major drug treatments are expected.
docs.snippet: Decisions on several major drug treatments are expected.

docs.lead_paragraph: In an election cycle defined by concerns over jobs and mortgages, government spending and debt, the issue of illegal immigration has become a common talking point.

headline.seo: Anti-Immigrant Focus in, of All Places, Nebraska
headline.main: Immigration Law Moves to Center Stage
headline.print_headline: Growing Anti-Immigrant Sentiments in an Unlikely State

docs.snippet: In an election cycle defined by concerns over jobs and mortgages, government spending and debt, the issue of illegal immigration has become a common talking point.

headline.main: Cycling Fans Reach for the Science Books

docs.abstract: The more you follow professional cycling, the more you wish you'd gone to medical school first.
docs.snippet: The more you follow professional cycling, the more you wish you'd gone to medical school first.
